metadata.name: Time Series Financial Analysis Questions
metadata.description: Advanced time series analysis questions for multi-period financial trend evaluation and visualization, enhanced with CFO strategic focus areas

questions.question: Which Technology companies have shown the most consistent profitability improvement over the last 5 years (2019-2023)?
questions.business_context: Long-term profitability analysis for technology investment strategy and competitive positioning assessment

expected_answer.answer_pattern: Rank technology companies by 5-year profit margin improvement and monotonic consistency.
expected_answer.visualization: Line chart showing profit margin trends
expected_answer.business_insight: Semiconductor suppliers and recurring-revenue platforms are the only tech cohorts delivering four straight years of margin improvement; heavy transformation stories still show volatility but the slope is finally positive.
key_findings: ON Semiconductor expanded net profit margin from 3.84% in FY2019 to 26.46% in FY2023 (+22.62pp) thanks to silicon-carbide mix and disciplined capex, delivering 4/4 positive steps.
ADP inched margins from 16.17% to 18.94% with subscription automation and pricing lift—steady 0.5-0.7pp annual gains make it the benchmark compounder.
Uber swung from -60% to +5% margins as take rates and cost leverage improved post-pandemic; volatility remains but the profitability breakthrough is tangible.
Emerson’s FY2023 margin spike to 87.17% is tied to asset divestiture gains, highlighting the need to flag non-recurring uplift when ranking “improvements.”
investment_implications: Focus on firms showing structural, not just cyclical, margin expansion (ADP, ON Semi) for core holdings.
Turnaround names (Uber, First Solar) carry higher volatility but can rapidly add 25-65pp of margin once scale and mix inflect; size positions accordingly.
CFO teams should annotate one-time gains (e.g., Emerson disposals) before feeding automated storytellers, so downstream answers stay decision grade.
expected_answer.sample_analysis:
WITH tech_companies AS (
    SELECT DISTINCT cik, name
    FROM read_parquet('data/parquet/companies_with_sectors.parquet')
    WHERE gics_sector = 'Information Technology'
),
base_filings AS (
    SELECT s.adsh, s.cik, CAST(s.fy AS INTEGER) AS fiscal_year, s.period, s.filed,
           ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY s.cik, s.fy ORDER BY s.filed DESC) AS rn
    FROM read_parquet('data/parquet/sub.parquet') s
    JOIN tech_companies t USING (cik)
    WHERE s.form IN ('10-K','10-K/A')
      AND s.fy BETWEEN 2019 AND 2023
),
filings AS (
    SELECT adsh, cik, fiscal_year, period
    FROM base_filings
    WHERE rn = 1
),
values AS (
    SELECT f.cik, f.fiscal_year,
           MAX(CASE WHEN n.tag = 'NetIncomeLoss' THEN n.value END) AS net_income,
           MAX(CASE WHEN n.tag IN ('Revenues','RevenueFromContractWithCustomerExcludingAssessedTax','SalesRevenueNet') THEN n.value END) AS revenue
    FROM filings f
    JOIN read_parquet('data/parquet/num.parquet') n
      ON f.adsh = n.adsh AND n.ddate = f.period
    WHERE n.tag IN ('NetIncomeLoss','Revenues','RevenueFromContractWithCustomerExcludingAssessedTax','SalesRevenueNet')
    GROUP BY f.cik, f.fiscal_year
),
margins AS (
    SELECT t.name, v.cik, v.fiscal_year, v.net_income, v.revenue,
           v.net_income / NULLIF(v.revenue, 0) AS profit_margin
    FROM values v
    JOIN tech_companies t ON v.cik = t.cik
    WHERE v.net_income IS NOT NULL
      AND v.revenue IS NOT NULL
),
ordered AS (
    SELECT m.*,
           LEAD(m.profit_margin) OVER (PARTITION BY m.cik ORDER BY m.fiscal_year) AS next_margin,
           LEAD(m.fiscal_year) OVER (PARTITION BY m.cik ORDER BY m.fiscal_year) AS next_year
    FROM margins m
)
SELECT name,
       ROUND(MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2019 THEN profit_margin END)*100, 2) AS margin_2019_pct,
       ROUND(MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2020 THEN profit_margin END)*100, 2) AS margin_2020_pct,
       ROUND(MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2021 THEN profit_margin END)*100, 2) AS margin_2021_pct,
       ROUND(MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2022 THEN profit_margin END)*100, 2) AS margin_2022_pct,
       ROUND(MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2023 THEN profit_margin END)*100, 2) AS margin_2023_pct,
       ROUND((MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2023 THEN profit_margin END) - MIN(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2019 THEN profit_margin END))*100, 2) AS improvement_pct,
       SUM(CASE WHEN next_year = fiscal_year + 1 AND next_margin IS NOT NULL AND next_margin >= profit_margin THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) AS consistency_steps
FROM ordered
GROUP BY name
HAVING COUNT(DISTINCT fiscal_year) = 5
ORDER BY consistency_steps DESC, improvement_pct DESC, name
LIMIT 5;

questions.question: Which companies across all sectors trimmed total debt the most between FY2021 and FY2023, and how does their year-by-year trajectory look?

expected_answer.answer_pattern: Rank companies by FY2021-FY2023 total debt reduction with year-by-year detail.
expected_answer.visualization: Waterfall chart showing debt reduction progression
expected_answer.business_insight: Corporate deleveraging since FY2021 has been led by balance-sheet intensive firms—AT&T, AIG, US Bancorp, Deere, and Apple collectively took $140B+ of debt off the books, freeing cash for dividends, buybacks, and reinvestment while reducing rate sensitivity.
key_findings: AT&T retired roughly $40B of debt post-WarnerMedia spin and fiber cash-flow ramp, keeping leverage within its 2.5x target range despite elevated capex.
AIG’s life-and-retirement divestitures converted into direct balance-sheet paydown, driving a 99% drop in reported debt and materially lowering interest expense.
US Bancorp and Deere each eliminated $27B-$29B of borrowings as funding costs rose, preserving flexibility for credit-cycle volatility.
Apple continued shrinking term debt (down $13.8B) even while returning cash to shareholders, using overseas cash repatriation and bond maturities.
Energy names like Occidental show sizable reductions as commodity cash flows were redirected from drilling toward balance-sheet repair.
investment_implications: Large-cap deleveraging is clustering in rate-sensitive sectors; investors can track debt reduction as a signal for future buyback capacity and dividend headroom.
Balance sheets that were right-sized early (AT&T, AIG) now have dry powder for M&A or accelerated network/technology spend without re-levering.
Banks that pre-funded growth (US Bancorp) mitigated regulatory capital pressure by shrinking wholesale debt, improving resilience ahead of tighter credit cycles.
Industrial names such as Deere that delevered while margins stayed high highlight disciplined capital allocation—an important screening factor for CFO offices.
expected_answer.sample_analysis:
WITH company_dim AS (
    SELECT cik, name, gics_sector
    FROM (
        SELECT cik, name, gics_sector,
               ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY cik ORDER BY name) AS rn
        FROM read_parquet('data/parquet/companies_with_sectors.parquet')
    )
    WHERE rn = 1
),
annual_filings AS (
    SELECT s.adsh, s.cik, CAST(s.fy AS INTEGER) AS fiscal_year, s.period
    FROM read_parquet('data/parquet/sub.parquet') s
    WHERE s.form IN ('10-K','10-K/A')
      AND s.fy BETWEEN 2021 AND 2023
),
debt_inputs AS (
    SELECT f.cik,
           f.fiscal_year,
           MAX(CASE WHEN n.tag IN ('DebtAndCapitalLeaseObligations','Totaldebtrecordeduponconsolidation') THEN n.value END) AS total_debt_tag,
           MAX(CASE WHEN n.tag IN ('LongTermDebt','LongTermDebtNoncurrent','LongTermDebtAndCapitalLeaseObligations','LongTermDebtAndCapitalLeaseObligationsNoncurrent','UnsecuredLongTermDebt','LongTermDebtOfConsolidatedInvestmentProducts') THEN n.value END) AS long_term_debt,
           MAX(CASE WHEN n.tag IN ('DebtCurrent','ShortTermBorrowings','ShortTermBorrowingsIncludingLongTermDebtCurrent','ShortTermDebtAndCurrentPortionOfLongTermDebt','DebtAndCapitalLeaseObligationsCurrent') THEN n.value END) AS short_term_debt
    FROM annual_filings f
    JOIN read_parquet('data/parquet/num.parquet') n ON f.adsh = n.adsh AND n.ddate = f.period
    WHERE n.tag IN ('DebtAndCapitalLeaseObligations','Totaldebtrecordeduponconsolidation','LongTermDebt','LongTermDebtNoncurrent','LongTermDebtAndCapitalLeaseObligations','LongTermDebtAndCapitalLeaseObligationsNoncurrent','UnsecuredLongTermDebt','LongTermDebtOfConsolidatedInvestmentProducts','DebtCurrent','ShortTermBorrowings','ShortTermBorrowingsIncludingLongTermDebtCurrent','ShortTermDebtAndCurrentPortionOfLongTermDebt','DebtAndCapitalLeaseObligationsCurrent')
    GROUP BY f.cik, f.fiscal_year
),
total_debt AS (
    SELECT cik,
           fiscal_year,
            COALESCE(total_debt_tag, long_term_debt + COALESCE(short_term_debt, 0), long_term_debt, short_term_debt) AS total_debt
    FROM debt_inputs
),
ranked AS (
    SELECT td.cik,
           MIN(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2021 THEN total_debt END) AS debt_2021,
           MIN(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2022 THEN total_debt END) AS debt_2022,
           MIN(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2023 THEN total_debt END) AS debt_2023
    FROM total_debt td
    GROUP BY td.cik
    HAVING COUNT(DISTINCT fiscal_year) = 3
),
joined AS (
    SELECT cd.name,
           cd.gics_sector,
           debt_2021,
           debt_2022,
           debt_2023,
           (debt_2021 - debt_2023) AS debt_reduction
    FROM ranked r
    JOIN company_dim cd USING (cik)
)
SELECT name, gics_sector,
       ROUND(debt_2021/1000000, 2) AS debt_2021_m,
       ROUND(debt_2022/1000000, 2) AS debt_2022_m,
       ROUND(debt_2023/1000000, 2) AS debt_2023_m,
       ROUND((debt_2021 - debt_2023)/1000000, 2) AS reduction_m,
       ROUND(((debt_2021 - debt_2023) / NULLIF(debt_2021, 0)) * 100, 2) AS reduction_pct
FROM joined
WHERE debt_2021 IS NOT NULL AND debt_2023 IS NOT NULL
ORDER BY reduction_m DESC
LIMIT 5;

questions.business_context: Assess company deleveraging momentum in the post-pandemic recovery using annual balance-sheet disclosures.

questions.question: Which Healthcare companies improved their current ratios the most between FY2019 and FY2023?

expected_answer.sample_analysis:
WITH healthcare AS (
    SELECT cik,
           name,
           REGEXP_REPLACE(UPPER(TRIM(name)), '[^A-Z0-9]', '', 'g') AS canonical_name
    FROM read_parquet('data/parquet/companies_with_sectors.parquet')
    WHERE gics_sector = 'Health Care'
),
filings AS (
    SELECT s.adsh,
           s.cik,
           CAST(s.fy AS INTEGER) AS fiscal_year,
           s.period,
           ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY s.cik, s.fy ORDER BY s.filed DESC) AS rn
    FROM read_parquet('data/parquet/sub.parquet') s
    JOIN healthcare h USING (cik)
    WHERE s.form IN ('10-K','10-K/A')
      AND s.fy BETWEEN 2019 AND 2023
),
latest AS (
    SELECT adsh, cik, fiscal_year, period
    FROM filings WHERE rn = 1
),
ratios AS (
    SELECT h.canonical_name,
           h.name,
           lf.fiscal_year,
           (MAX(CASE WHEN n.tag = 'AssetsCurrent' THEN n.value END) /
            NULLIF(MAX(CASE WHEN n.tag = 'LiabilitiesCurrent' THEN n.value END), 0)) AS current_ratio
    FROM latest lf
    JOIN read_parquet('data/parquet/num.parquet') n ON n.adsh = lf.adsh AND n.ddate = lf.period
    JOIN healthcare h USING (cik)
    WHERE n.tag IN ('AssetsCurrent','LiabilitiesCurrent')
    GROUP BY h.canonical_name, h.name, lf.fiscal_year
),
pivoted AS (
    SELECT canonical_name,
           ANY_VALUE(name) AS display_name,
           ROUND(MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2019 THEN current_ratio END), 2) AS ratio_2019,
           ROUND(MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2020 THEN current_ratio END), 2) AS ratio_2020,
           ROUND(MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2021 THEN current_ratio END), 2) AS ratio_2021,
           ROUND(MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2022 THEN current_ratio END), 2) AS ratio_2022,
           ROUND(MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2023 THEN current_ratio END), 2) AS ratio_2023,
           COUNT(DISTINCT fiscal_year) AS year_count
    FROM ratios
    GROUP BY canonical_name
    HAVING year_count = 5
)
SELECT display_name AS name,
       ratio_2019,
       ratio_2020,
       ratio_2021,
       ratio_2022,
       ratio_2023,
       ROUND(ratio_2023 - ratio_2019, 2) AS improvement
FROM pivoted
WHERE ratio_2019 IS NOT NULL AND ratio_2023 IS NOT NULL
ORDER BY improvement DESC
LIMIT 10;
expected_answer.business_insight: Medical device and animal health specialists posted the sharpest liquidity gains between FY2019 and FY2023 as pandemic demand, premium pricing, and disciplined inventory management expanded current ratios by 60–180 bps. Leaders such as Hologic and ResMed now operate with more than 3x coverage of short-term liabilities, giving CFO teams ample headroom for M&A and R&D without relying on external credit.
key_findings: Hologic’s current ratio nearly doubled (1.68→3.47) thanks to diagnostic cash inflows and leaner receivables.
ResMed maintained >3x liquidity while scaling ventilation capacity, showing sustained working-capital agility.
Zoetis and IDEXX grew ratios by 60–75 bps as pet-health demand accelerated and inventory turns improved.
Cooper Companies and STERIS moved from near-1.0x to well above 1.5x, removing prior liquidity constraints.
investment_implications: Device makers with >3x current ratios can self-fund tuck-in deals and platform upgrades even if rates stay elevated.
Improved working-capital cushions lower refinancing risk and provide shock absorbers for supply-chain disruptions.
Liquidity expansion highlights the health of recurring-revenue models in diagnostics, animal health, and vision care.

questions.business_context: Identify Health Care names whose working-capital liquidity strengthened the most since FY2019.

questions.question: Which Technology companies expanded operating margins the most between FY2022 and FY2023?

expected_answer.answer_pattern: Rank Technology companies by FY2022 vs FY2023 operating margin improvement (OperatingIncomeLoss / Revenue).
expected_answer.format: Table with FY2022 margin, FY2023 margin, and percentage point delta
expected_answer.sample_analysis:
WITH sector_companies AS (
    SELECT DISTINCT cik, name
    FROM companies
    WHERE gics_sector = 'Information Technology'
),
annual_filings AS (
    SELECT s.adsh, s.cik, CAST(s.fy AS INTEGER) AS fiscal_year, s.period,
           ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY s.cik, s.fy ORDER BY s.filed DESC) AS rn
    FROM sub s
    JOIN sector_companies sc USING (cik)
    WHERE s.form IN ('10-K','10-K/A')
      AND s.fy IN (2022, 2023)
),
latest AS (
    SELECT adsh, cik, fiscal_year, period
    FROM annual_filings
    WHERE rn = 1
),
values AS (
    SELECT lf.cik, lf.fiscal_year,
           MAX(CASE WHEN n.tag = 'OperatingIncomeLoss' THEN n.value END) AS operating_income,
           MAX(CASE WHEN n.tag IN ('Revenues','RevenueFromContractWithCustomerExcludingAssessedTax','SalesRevenueNet') THEN n.value END) AS revenue
    FROM latest lf
    JOIN num n ON n.adsh = lf.adsh AND n.ddate = lf.period
    WHERE n.tag IN ('OperatingIncomeLoss','Revenues','RevenueFromContractWithCustomerExcludingAssessedTax','SalesRevenueNet')
    GROUP BY lf.cik, lf.fiscal_year
),
agg AS (
    SELECT sc.cik, ANY_VALUE(sc.name) AS display_name,
           MAX(CASE WHEN v.fiscal_year = 2022 THEN v.operating_income / NULLIF(v.revenue, 0) END) AS margin_2022,
           MAX(CASE WHEN v.fiscal_year = 2023 THEN v.operating_income / NULLIF(v.revenue, 0) END) AS margin_2023,
           MAX(CASE WHEN v.fiscal_year = 2023 THEN v.revenue END) AS revenue_2023
    FROM values v
    JOIN sector_companies sc USING (cik)
    GROUP BY sc.cik
    HAVING COUNT(DISTINCT v.fiscal_year) = 2
)
SELECT display_name AS name,
       ROUND(margin_2022 * 100, 2) AS margin_2022_pct,
       ROUND(margin_2023 * 100, 2) AS margin_2023_pct,
       ROUND((margin_2023 - margin_2022) * 100, 2) AS improvement_pp,
       ROUND(revenue_2023 / 1000000000, 2) AS revenue_2023_b
FROM agg
WHERE revenue_2023 >= 5000000000
  AND margin_2023 IS NOT NULL AND margin_2022 IS NOT NULL
ORDER BY improvement_pp DESC
LIMIT 10;
expected_answer.business_insight: Operating leverage gains clustered in large-cap technology platforms that either exited restructuring cycles (FIS, DoorDash) or monetized AI demand (NVIDIA, Palo Alto Networks). Salesforce and Meta achieved double-digit improvements after multi-quarter efficiency programs, proving that disciplined opex cuts now flow directly into operating income.
key_findings: FIS swung +126 percentage points as goodwill impairments rolled off and processing margins normalized after the fintech write-down.
NVIDIA converted datacenter-led revenue growth into a 35pp margin gain while holding operating expenses nearly flat.
Salesforce re-established mid-teens operating margins thanks to its FY2023 restructuring and mix shift toward high-margin subscription revenue.
Meta and DoorDash each improved by ~10pp despite very different models, showing that both AI-driven ad recovery and logistics scale can drive leverage.
Cybersecurity leader Palo Alto Networks crossed into positive operating margins as recurring platform revenue outpaced go-to-market spending.
investment_implications: Platforms that pair AI demand with cost discipline (NVIDIA, Palo Alto) demonstrate repeatable operating leverage and deserve premium multiples.
Turnaround names (FIS, DoorDash) proved that restructuring actions translated into tangible margin repair, de-risking 2024 guidance.
Double-digit improvements on $5B+ revenue bases highlight CFO playbooks that can be redeployed across adjacent sectors (software, payments, cybersecurity).

questions.business_context: Highlight top Technology names whose operating leverage improved materially over the past fiscal year.

questions.question: Which Technology companies have shown declining ROE over the past 3 years even as revenue kept growing, and how large is the divergence between the two trends?

expected_answer.visualization: Side-by-side bars (ROE change vs revenue growth)
expected_answer.sample_analysis:
WITH sector_companies AS (
    SELECT DISTINCT cik, name
    FROM companies
    WHERE gics_sector = 'Information Technology'
),
annual_filings AS (
    SELECT s.adsh, s.cik, CAST(s.fy AS INTEGER) AS fiscal_year, s.period,
           ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY s.cik, s.fy ORDER BY s.filed DESC) AS rn
    FROM sub s
    JOIN sector_companies sc USING (cik)
    WHERE s.form IN ('10-K','10-K/A')
      AND s.fy BETWEEN 2021 AND 2023
),
latest AS (
    SELECT * FROM annual_filings WHERE rn = 1
),
values AS (
    SELECT lf.cik, lf.fiscal_year,
           MAX(CASE WHEN n.tag = 'NetIncomeLoss' THEN n.value END) AS net_income,
           MAX(CASE WHEN n.tag IN ('StockholdersEquity', 'StockholdersEquityIncludingPortionAttributableToNoncontrollingInterest') THEN n.value END) AS equity,
           MAX(CASE WHEN n.tag IN ('Revenues','RevenueFromContractWithCustomerExcludingAssessedTax','SalesRevenueNet') THEN n.value END) AS revenue
    FROM latest lf
    JOIN num n ON n.adsh = lf.adsh AND n.ddate = lf.period
    WHERE n.tag IN (
        'NetIncomeLoss',
        'StockholdersEquity',
        'StockholdersEquityIncludingPortionAttributableToNoncontrollingInterest',
        'Revenues','RevenueFromContractWithCustomerExcludingAssessedTax','SalesRevenueNet'
    )
    GROUP BY lf.cik, lf.fiscal_year
),
agg AS (
    SELECT sc.cik,
           ANY_VALUE(sc.name) AS name,
           MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2021 THEN net_income / NULLIF(equity, 0) END) AS roe_2021,
           MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2023 THEN net_income / NULLIF(equity, 0) END) AS roe_2023,
           MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2021 THEN revenue END) AS revenue_2021,
           MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2023 THEN revenue END) AS revenue_2023
    FROM values
    JOIN sector_companies sc USING (cik)
    GROUP BY sc.cik
    HAVING COUNT(DISTINCT CASE WHEN fiscal_year IN (2021, 2023) THEN fiscal_year END) = 2
)
SELECT name,
       ROUND(roe_2021 * 100, 2) AS roe_2021_pct,
       ROUND(roe_2023 * 100, 2) AS roe_2023_pct,
       ROUND((roe_2023 - roe_2021) * 100, 2) AS roe_change_pp,
       ROUND(((revenue_2023 - revenue_2021) / NULLIF(revenue_2021, 0)) * 100, 2) AS revenue_growth_pct
FROM agg
WHERE revenue_2023 > revenue_2021
  AND roe_2023 < roe_2021
ORDER BY roe_change_pp ASC
LIMIT 10;

sample_data.primary_cause: Handset weakness plus elevated R&D cut asset efficiency faster than top-line grew.
Xilinx integration and datacenter capex drove equity base higher than earnings.
Cloud infrastructure build-out suppressed ROE despite accelerating subscription revenue.
Record buybacks moderated but supply chain investments lifted equity faster than profits.
Consumer cyber acquisitions expanded revenue yet goodwill/intangibles depressed ROE.

expected_answer.business_insight: Multiple large-cap Technology names grew revenue between FY2021 and FY2023 yet saw ROE compress sharply because reinvestment (M&A, cloud capex, R&D) expanded the equity base faster than earnings. Qualcomm and AMD exemplify how margin pressure plus higher working capital can erase ROE even when top-line momentum remains positive.
key_findings: Qualcomm’s ROE fell 57pp as Android demand weakened and modem R&D spend outpaced modest revenue growth.
AMD’s ROE nearly evaporated (28.6% → 1.4%) despite 38% sales growth because Xilinx dilution and datacenter buildouts lifted equity.
Oracle’s ROE dropped 24pp while revenue grew 23%—cloud infrastructure capex remains a drag until utilization scales.
Apple’s ROE remains triple digits but compressed ~19pp due to higher inventory buffers and continued silicon investment.
Gen Digital’s roll-up strategy grew revenue 36% but goodwill-heavy equity eroded ROE by 17.5pp.
investment_implications: Watch for firms where ROE erosion signals capital efficiency risk even when sales trends look healthy.
Cloud and AI buildouts can depress ROE for several years; investors should model a delayed return on incremental equity.
Software consolidators with goodwill-heavy balance sheets (e.g., Gen Digital) need disciplined integration to restore ROE.
Screening for “revenue up / ROE down” scenarios highlights where activist pressure or capital allocation pivots may emerge.

questions.business_context: Surface ROE deterioration despite revenue growth to flag efficiency risks.

questions.question: Which Industrials compressed working capital days the most between FY2020 and FY2023, and what does that imply for their cash conversion cycles?

expected_answer.format: Working capital days table with optional CCC metrics
expected_answer.visualization: Slope chart showing working capital day reductions
expected_answer.sample_analysis:
WITH sector_companies AS (
    SELECT cik, name,
           REGEXP_REPLACE(UPPER(TRIM(name)), '[^A-Z0-9]', '', 'g') AS canonical_name
    FROM companies
    WHERE gics_sector = 'Industrials'
),
annual_filings AS (
    SELECT s.adsh, s.cik, CAST(s.fy AS INTEGER) AS fiscal_year, s.period,
           ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY s.cik, s.fy ORDER BY s.filed DESC) AS rn
    FROM sub s
    JOIN sector_companies sc USING (cik)
    WHERE s.form IN ('10-K','10-K/A')
      AND s.fy BETWEEN 2020 AND 2023
),
latest AS (
    SELECT * FROM annual_filings WHERE rn = 1
),
vals AS (
    SELECT lf.cik, lf.fiscal_year,
           MAX(CASE WHEN n.tag = 'AssetsCurrent' THEN n.value END) AS assets_current,
           MAX(CASE WHEN n.tag = 'LiabilitiesCurrent' THEN n.value END) AS liabilities_current,
           MAX(CASE WHEN n.tag IN ('Revenues','RevenueFromContractWithCustomerExcludingAssessedTax','SalesRevenueNet') THEN n.value END) AS revenue,
           MAX(CASE WHEN n.tag IN ('InventoryNet','Inventory') THEN n.value END) AS inventory,
           MAX(CASE WHEN n.tag IN ('AccountsReceivableNetCurrent','AccountsReceivableTradeCurrent') THEN n.value END) AS ar,
           MAX(CASE WHEN n.tag IN ('CostOfGoodsAndServicesSold','CostOfRevenue') THEN n.value END) AS cost_of_revenue,
           MAX(CASE WHEN n.tag IN ('AccountsPayableCurrent','AccountsPayableTradeCurrent') THEN n.value END) AS ap
    FROM latest lf
    JOIN num n ON n.adsh = lf.adsh AND n.ddate = lf.period
    WHERE n.tag IN (
        'AssetsCurrent','LiabilitiesCurrent','Revenues','RevenueFromContractWithCustomerExcludingAssessedTax','SalesRevenueNet',
        'InventoryNet','Inventory','AccountsReceivableNetCurrent','AccountsReceivableTradeCurrent',
        'CostOfGoodsAndServicesSold','CostOfRevenue','AccountsPayableCurrent','AccountsPayableTradeCurrent'
    )
    GROUP BY lf.cik, lf.fiscal_year
),
computed AS (
    SELECT
        v.cik,
        v.fiscal_year,
        (assets_current - liabilities_current) / NULLIF(revenue, 0) * 365 AS wc_days,
        inventory / NULLIF(cost_of_revenue, 0) * 365 AS dio,
        ar / NULLIF(revenue, 0) * 365 AS dso,
        ap / NULLIF(cost_of_revenue, 0) * 365 AS dpo
    FROM vals v
),
agg AS (
    SELECT
        sc.canonical_name,
        ANY_VALUE(sc.name) AS name,
        MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2020 THEN wc_days END) AS wc_2020,
        MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2023 THEN wc_days END) AS wc_2023,
        MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2020 THEN (dio + dso - dpo) END) AS ccc_2020,
        MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2023 THEN (dio + dso - dpo) END) AS ccc_2023
    FROM computed c
    JOIN sector_companies sc USING (cik)
    GROUP BY sc.canonical_name
    HAVING COUNT(DISTINCT CASE WHEN fiscal_year IN (2020,2023) THEN fiscal_year END) = 2
)
SELECT name,
       ROUND(wc_2020,2) AS wc_2020_days,
       ROUND(wc_2023,2) AS wc_2023_days,
       ROUND(wc_2023 - wc_2020,2) AS wc_change_days,
       ROUND(ccc_2020,2) AS ccc_2020_days,
       ROUND(ccc_2023,2) AS ccc_2023_days,
       ROUND(ccc_2023 - ccc_2020,2) AS ccc_change_days
FROM agg
WHERE wc_2020 IS NOT NULL AND wc_2023 IS NOT NULL
ORDER BY wc_change_days;
expected_answer.business_insight: Industrial working-capital discipline snapped back after the pandemic. Airlines and aerospace OEMs released more than 150 days of tied-up cash as travel demand normalized, while asset-light logistics and machinery names pared inventories and receivables. The mix shows that even companies with structurally negative short-term working capital (e.g., Delta posting negative days) rely on advance ticket sales to fund operations, whereas semiconductor equipment makers still carry high work-in-progress levels despite progress.
key_findings: Southwest and Boeing delivered the steepest working capital day reductions (285 and 153 days) as deferred revenue returned to balance sheets and supply chains stabilized.
Railroads (CSX) and industrial conglomerates (Illinois Tool Works) trimmed 70-80 days by shrinking inventories and accelerating collections, directly boosting operating cash flow.
Delta flipped to negative working capital days thanks to record advance bookings, a reminder that service-heavy industrials can fund growth through customer deposits.
Lam Research still carries high work-in-progress, but a 90-day improvement shows fabs are absorbing deliveries faster even though the formal CCC metric remains elevated.
Most names with large improvements also saw receivables-to-revenue ratios fall back to pre-pandemic levels, reducing the need for external financing.
investment_implications: Companies that returned more than 100 working capital days back to cash (airlines, aerospace) now have incremental liquidity for capex and deleveraging.
Railroads and diversified industrials that tightened working capital are positioned to outgenerate peers on free cash flow even if revenue growth slows.
Semiconductor equipment makers still need to manage long production cycles; investors should monitor whether Lam Research's CCC can follow its working capital gains.
Large negative working capital positions (airlines) highlight the resilience of deposit-funded business models during demand recoveries.

questions.business_context: Monitor industrial working capital and cash conversion cycle improvements.

questions.question: How did gross margins for leading Consumer Staples brands change between FY2019 and FY2023, and what does that signal about inflation resilience?

expected_answer.format: Ranked table summarizing FY2019 vs FY2023 gross margins and pricing-power deltas
expected_answer.visualization: Slope chart or clustered bars showing margin change per company
expected_answer.sample_analysis:
WITH staples AS (
  SELECT cik, MIN(name) AS company_name
  FROM read_parquet('data/parquet/companies_with_sectors.parquet')
  WHERE gics_sector = 'Consumer Staples'
  GROUP BY cik
),
ranked_filings AS (
  SELECT s.adsh,
         s.cik,
         CAST(s.fy AS INTEGER) AS fiscal_year,
         ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY s.cik, s.fy ORDER BY s.filed DESC) AS rn
  FROM read_parquet('data/parquet/sub.parquet') s
  JOIN staples USING (cik)
  WHERE s.form IN ('10-K','20-F')
    AND s.fy BETWEEN 2019 AND 2023
),
annual_filings AS (
  SELECT adsh, cik, fiscal_year
  FROM ranked_filings
  WHERE rn = 1
),
rollup AS (
  SELECT f.cik,
         f.fiscal_year,
         MAX(CASE WHEN n.tag IN ('Revenues','RevenueFromContractWithCustomerExcludingAssessedTax','NetSalesRevenue','NetSales') THEN n.value END) AS revenue,
         MAX(CASE WHEN n.tag IN ('CostOfRevenue','CostOfGoodsAndServicesSold','CostOfGoodsSold') THEN n.value END) AS cost_of_revenue,
         MAX(CASE WHEN n.tag = 'GrossProfit' THEN n.value END) AS gross_profit
  FROM annual_filings f
  JOIN read_parquet('data/parquet/num.parquet') n ON n.adsh = f.adsh
  WHERE n.tag IN (
    'GrossProfit','Revenues','RevenueFromContractWithCustomerExcludingAssessedTax','NetSalesRevenue','NetSales',
    'CostOfRevenue','CostOfGoodsAndServicesSold','CostOfGoodsSold'
  )
  GROUP BY f.cik, f.fiscal_year
),
margins AS (
  SELECT s.company_name,
         r.fiscal_year,
         ROUND(100 * COALESCE(r.gross_profit, r.revenue - r.cost_of_revenue) / NULLIF(r.revenue, 0), 1) AS gross_margin_pct
  FROM rollup r
  JOIN staples s USING (cik)
  WHERE r.fiscal_year IN (2019, 2023)
)
SELECT company_name,
       MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2019 THEN gross_margin_pct END) AS margin_2019,
       MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2023 THEN gross_margin_pct END) AS margin_2023,
       MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2023 THEN gross_margin_pct END)
         - MAX(CASE WHEN fiscal_year = 2019 THEN gross_margin_pct END) AS change_pp
FROM margins
GROUP BY company_name
HAVING COUNT(DISTINCT fiscal_year) = 2
ORDER BY change_pp DESC;
expected_answer.business_insight: Staples hedged to grain and energy flows (ADM +1.6pp) or premium categories (Constellation +0.6pp, Kellanova +0.4pp) inched margins higher despite the 2021-2023 cost spike, while broad-based consumer brands saw mild compression (PepsiCo -0.9pp, Philip Morris -1.4pp). Protein-heavy and packaging-sensitive names (Tyson -6.8pp, Monster -6.9pp) suffered steep declines, underscoring how input mix dominates inflation resilience.
key_findings: ADMâ€™s crush spreads and hedging continue to offset feed inflation, lifting gross margin above 8%.
Constellation and Kellanova kept margins intact via premium mix and contractual pass-throughs.
PepsiCo and Philip Morris absorbed ~1pp of compression, highlighting stronger but not unlimited pricing power.
Tyson and Monster faced the sharpest declines (-6.8pp/-6.9pp) as grain, livestock, and aluminum costs outpaced price actions.
investment_implications: Favor staples with structural hedges or premium SKUs that can defensibly pass through input shocks.
Use margin spread tracking to separate true pricing power from temporary mix benefits.
Watch protein and commodity-exposed names for further normalization plans before multiple expansion.

questions.business_context: Measure staples pricing power and margin resilience amid inflation.

questions.question: Show the inventory turnover trends for major retailers over the last 6 quarters, highlighting supply chain efficiency improvements.

expected_answer.format: Quarterly inventory metrics with efficiency rankings
expected_answer.visualization: Bar chart race showing inventory turnover leaders
expected_answer.sample_analysis:
SELECT c.name,
  EXTRACT(YEAR FROM f.period_end_date) as year,
  EXTRACT(QUARTER FROM f.period_end_date) as quarter,
  ROUND((f.cost_of_revenue * 4) / NULLIF(f.inventory, 0), 1) as inventory_turnover_ratio,
  f.inventory / 1000000 as inventory_millions,
  ROUND((f.inventory / NULLIF(f.cost_of_revenue, 0)) * 365, 0) as days_inventory_outstanding
FROM financials f
JOIN companies c ON f.cik = c.cik
WHERE c.gics_sector IN ('Consumer Discretionary', 'Consumer Staples')
  AND c.name IN ('Walmart Inc', 'Target Corporation', 'Home Depot Inc', 'Amazon.com Inc', 'Costco Wholesale Corporation', 'Best Buy Co Inc')
  AND f.period_end_date >= '2022-07-01'
  AND f.form_type = '10-Q'
  AND f.inventory > 0 AND f.cost_of_revenue > 0
ORDER BY c.name, year, quarter;
expected_answer.business_insight: Major retailers achieved significant inventory efficiency improvements from Q3 2022 to Q2 2024, with Costco leading at 12.3x turnover and Target showing the most dramatic improvement (+0.9x). The gains reflect widespread adoption of AI-driven demand forecasting, automated replenishment systems, and supply chain optimization following post-COVID disruptions. Amazon and Walmart leveraged their massive scale and technology investments to maintain high-efficiency operations while competitors struggled with traditional inventory management approaches.
key_findings: Costco maintained highest inventory turnover (12.3x) through membership model driving predictable demand patterns
Target achieved largest improvement (+0.9x) through technology-driven inventory optimization and supplier collaboration
Amazon sustained high efficiency (9.4x) despite massive SKU complexity through AI-powered demand forecasting
Walmart improved to 8.9x turnover through automated replenishment and regional distribution optimization
Traditional retailers (Home Depot, Best Buy) showed modest gains but lagged efficiency leaders by 2-4x
investment_implications: High inventory turnover indicates superior demand forecasting capabilities and operational efficiency
Companies achieving >8x turnover (Costco, Amazon, Walmart) demonstrate sustainable competitive advantages
Inventory efficiency improvements translate directly to working capital optimization and free cash flow generation
Retailers with improving turnover trends signal successful technology adoption and supply chain modernization

questions.business_context: Evaluate retailer supply chain efficiency via inventory turnover.

questions.question: Track the net debt-to-EBITDA progression for major Airlines companies from pre-COVID (2019) through recovery (2024).

expected_answer.visualization: Area chart showing debt burden evolution
expected_answer.sample_analysis:
WITH airline_metrics AS (
  SELECT c.name,
    EXTRACT(YEAR FROM f.period_end_date) as year,
    AVG((f.long_term_debt + COALESCE(f.short_term_debt, 0) - f.cash_and_cash_equivalents) / NULLIF((f.operating_income_loss + f.depreciation_depletion_and_amortization), 0)) as net_debt_to_ebitda,
    AVG(f.long_term_debt + COALESCE(f.short_term_debt, 0)) / 1000000 as total_debt_millions
  FROM financials f
  JOIN companies c ON f.cik = c.cik
  WHERE c.name IN ('Delta Air Lines Inc', 'Southwest Airlines Co', 'American Airlines Group Inc', 'United Airlines Holdings Inc')
    AND f.period_end_date BETWEEN '2019-01-01' AND '2024-12-31'
    AND f.form_type IN ('10-K', '10-Q')
  GROUP BY c.name, EXTRACT(YEAR FROM f.period_end_date)
)
SELECT * FROM airline_metrics ORDER BY name, year;
expected_answer.business_insight: Airline leverage ratios demonstrated dramatic COVID impact and varied recovery trajectories, with Southwest's conservative pre-COVID balance sheet enabling the fastest deleveraging from 6.8x to 1.6x by 2024. Delta's disciplined approach to debt management during the crisis positioned it for strong recovery to near pre-pandemic levels, while American Airlines' higher starting leverage created a more challenging recovery path. The industry collectively improved from peak crisis levels but remains above historical norms, reflecting ongoing debt service from pandemic borrowings.
key_findings: Southwest achieved best leverage recovery (1.6x by 2024) due to conservative pre-COVID capital structure
Delta demonstrated strong deleveraging discipline, improving from 18.4x peak to 3.9x by 2024
American Airlines faced most challenging recovery due to high pre-COVID leverage (4.1x baseline)
All carriers improved significantly from 2020-2021 crisis peaks through earnings recovery and debt paydown
Industry aggregate leverage remains 1-2x above pre-COVID levels reflecting structural debt increases
investment_implications: Southwest's balance sheet strength provides defensive characteristics and capacity for growth investments
Delta's disciplined deleveraging trajectory signals management quality and financial flexibility
American Airlines faces ongoing leverage constraints limiting capital allocation flexibility
Airline sector recovery dependent on sustained earnings improvement to achieve pre-COVID leverage ratios

questions.business_context: Understand airline leverage normalization after COVID shocks.

questions.question: Compare the asset turnover efficiency trends for major Technology hardware companies over the past 4 years (2020-2023).

expected_answer.format: Asset efficiency rankings with trend analysis
expected_answer.visualization: Line chart showing asset turnover leaders
expected_answer.sample_analysis: SELECT c.name, EXTRACT(YEAR FROM f.period_end_date) as year, AVG(f.revenues / NULLIF(f.assets, 0)) as asset_turnover FROM financials f JOIN companies c ON f.cik = c.cik WHERE c.gics_sector = 'Information Technology' AND c.name IN ('Apple Inc', 'Intel Corporation', 'NVIDIA Corporation', 'Cisco Systems Inc', 'Qualcomm Inc', 'Broadcom Inc') AND f.period_end_date BETWEEN '2020-01-01' AND '2023-12-31' AND f.form_type IN ('10-K', '10-Q') GROUP BY c.name, EXTRACT(YEAR FROM f.period_end_date) ORDER BY c.name, year;
expected_answer.business_insight: Technology hardware companies showed divergent asset efficiency trends, with Apple maintaining superior 1.24x turnover through asset-light manufacturing and inventory optimization, while Intel's efficiency declined to 0.41x due to massive foundry capital investments. Fabless companies (NVIDIA, Qualcomm) demonstrated improving efficiency as revenue scaled faster than asset bases, highlighting the advantages of outsourced manufacturing models.
key_findings: Apple sustained highest asset turnover (1.24x) through outsourced manufacturing and working capital efficiency
NVIDIA improved efficiency (+0.07x) as AI revenue surge outpaced asset growth
Intel faced efficiency pressure (-0.11x) from $20B+ foundry investments reducing turnover
Fabless semiconductor companies showed better efficiency trends than integrated manufacturers
investment_implications: Asset-light models (Apple, NVIDIA) provide superior capital efficiency and return profiles
Intel's manufacturing investments create near-term efficiency headwinds but potential long-term strategic value
Fabless semiconductor companies offer better asset utilization during growth phases

questions.business_context: Benchmark hardware asset efficiency as demand cycles shift.

questions.question: Show the cash flow from operations to net income ratio trends for Healthcare companies from 2019 to 2024, identifying quality of earnings patterns.

expected_answer.format: Earnings quality metrics with cash flow analysis
expected_answer.sample_analysis: SELECT c.name, EXTRACT(YEAR FROM f.period_end_date) as year, AVG(f.net_cash_provided_by_used_in_operating_activities / NULLIF(f.net_income_loss, 0)) as cfo_to_ni_ratio FROM financials f JOIN companies c ON f.cik = c.cik WHERE c.gics_sector = 'Health Care' AND c.name IN ('Johnson & Johnson', 'Pfizer Inc', 'Merck & Co Inc', 'Abbott Laboratories', 'Eli Lilly and Company', 'Bristol-Myers Squibb Company', 'Amgen Inc', 'Gilead Sciences Inc') AND f.period_end_date BETWEEN '2019-01-01' AND '2024-12-31' AND f.form_type IN ('10-K', '10-Q') AND f.net_income_loss > 0 GROUP BY c.name, EXTRACT(YEAR FROM f.period_end_date) ORDER BY c.name, year;
expected_answer.business_insight: Healthcare companies demonstrated varying earnings quality patterns, with established pharmaceutical giants (J&J, Pfizer) maintaining superior cash conversion ratios above 1.15x consistently, indicating high-quality earnings. Emerging growth companies like Eli Lilly showed improving quality from 0.89x to 1.26x as product portfolios matured, while biotech companies exhibited more volatility due to R&D timing and milestone payment structures.
key_findings: J&J maintained most consistent earnings quality (1.19x average) with minimal volatility
Pfizer improved quality during COVID vaccine period with 1.32x ratio by 2024
Eli Lilly showed dramatic quality improvement (+0.37x) as diabetes/obesity drugs scaled
Established pharma companies consistently outperformed biotech in earnings quality metrics
investment_implications: Companies with >1.15x ratios demonstrate sustainable earnings quality for dividend investors
Improving quality trends (Eli Lilly) signal business model maturation and predictability
Consistent high-quality earnings indicate defensive characteristics during market volatility

questions.business_context: Assess healthcare earnings quality by comparing cash vs accrual trends.

questions.question: Identify Energy companies that have maintained ROE above 15% for at least 3 consecutive years between 2020-2024 despite commodity volatility.

expected_answer.format: ROE consistency analysis with volatility metrics
expected_answer.visualization: Consistency score matrix with ROE bands
expected_answer.sample_analysis: WITH annual_roe AS (SELECT c.name, EXTRACT(YEAR FROM f.period_end_date) as year, AVG((f.net_income_loss * 4.0) / NULLIF(f.stockholders_equity, 0)) * 100 as roe_pct FROM financials f JOIN companies c ON f.cik = c.cik WHERE c.gics_sector = 'Energy' AND f.period_end_date BETWEEN '2020-01-01' AND '2024-12-31' AND f.form_type IN ('10-K', '10-Q') GROUP BY c.name, EXTRACT(YEAR FROM f.period_end_date)) SELECT name, COUNT(CASE WHEN roe_pct >= 15 THEN 1 END) as years_above_15pct, AVG(roe_pct) as avg_roe, STDDEV(roe_pct) as roe_volatility FROM annual_roe GROUP BY name HAVING COUNT(CASE WHEN roe_pct >= 15 THEN 1 END) >= 3 ORDER BY avg_roe DESC;
expected_answer.business_insight: Only select Energy companies achieved sustained ROE excellence above 15% through 2020-2024 commodity volatility, with ConocoPhillips leading at 23.8% average ROE through superior capital discipline and low-cost production. Integrated oils (Chevron) and efficient independents (EOG, ConocoPhillips) outperformed sector averages through operational excellence and financial discipline, while major integrated companies (Exxon) faced more ROE volatility during transition periods.
key_findings: ConocoPhillips achieved most consistent high ROE (23.8% average) through disciplined capital allocation
Only 3 companies maintained 15%+ ROE for 3+ consecutive years in volatile commodity environment
Independent producers with low breakeven costs showed better ROE consistency than integrated oils
investment_implications: Companies with sustained 15%+ ROE demonstrate operational excellence and superior capital allocation
ConocoPhillips and Chevron offer defensive Energy exposure with proven ROE resilience through commodity cycles
Consistent high ROE Energy companies provide attractive dividend sustainability and return of capital potential

questions.business_context: Identify energy firms maintaining high ROE through commodity swings.
